verses.text: At that time the LORD said to me, 'Cut for yourself two stone tablets like the first, and come up to Me on the mountain, and make an ark of wood.'
verses.comment: This verse closely follows the Hebrew wording; 'ark of wood' refers to a chest made to hold the tablets.

verses.text: 'And I will write on the tablets the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke, and you shall put them in the ark.'
verses.comment: The wording maintains the direct speech and the action about the broken tablets.

verses.text: So I made an ark of acacia wood, and cut two stone tablets like the first, and went up the mountain with the two tablets in my hand.
verses.comment: Acacia is specified in the Hebrew. The phrase 'in my hand' simply means 'carrying'.

verses.text: And He wrote on the tablets, as at the first, the Ten Commandments that the LORD had spoken to you on the mountain out of the midst of the fire on the day of the assembly; and the LORD gave them to me.
verses.comment: "Ten Commandments" is literally "ten words" in Hebrew.

verses.text: Then I turned and came down from the mountain and put the tablets in the ark that I had made. And there they are, as the LORD commanded me.
verses.comment: "There they are" refers to being kept securely as per God's instructions.

verses.text: The sons of Israel set out from Beeroth Bene-jaakan to Moserah. There Aaron died, and there he was buried, and Eleazar his son served as priest in his place.
verses.comment: This travel notice is slightly rearranged compared to Numbers, but matches the Hebrew here.

verses.text: From there they traveled to Gudgodah, and from Gudgodah to Jotbathah, a land with streams of water.
verses.comment: Place names transliterated. 'A land with streams of water' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: At that time the LORD set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the ark of the covenant of the LORD, to stand before the LORD to serve Him, and to bless in His name to this day.
verses.comment: Levi’s roles listed match Levitical responsibilities.

verses.text: Therefore Levi has no portion or inheritance with his brothers; the LORD is his inheritance, as the LORD your God said to him.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Levites’ unique status. The wording closely matches the original.

verses.text: I stayed on the mountain, as at the first time, forty days and forty nights. And the LORD listened to me that time also; the LORD was not willing to destroy you.
verses.comment: Forty days and nights echoes Moses’ previous intercession.

verses.text: And the LORD said to me, 'Arise, go on your journey before the people, so that they may go in and possess the land, which I swore to their fathers to give them.'
verses.comment: God reaffirms His covenant promise.

verses.text: And now, Israel, what does the LORD your God ask from you, but to fear the LORD your God, to walk in all His ways, to love Him, to serve the LORD your God with all your heart and with all your soul,
verses.comment: Verse closely matches standard translations but uses contemporary readability.

verses.text: to keep the commandments of the LORD and His statutes, which I am commanding you today for your good?
verses.comment: Reasons for obedience made explicit.

verses.text: Behold, to the LORD your God belong heaven and the heaven of heavens, the earth with all that is in it.
verses.comment: 'Heaven of heavens' is a Hebrew expression for the highest heavens.

verses.text: Yet the LORD set His affection on your fathers and loved them, and He chose their descendants after them, you above all peoples, as you are this day.
verses.comment: 'Set His affection' is a literal rendering from the Hebrew 'chashaq'.

verses.text: So, circumcise the foreskin of your heart, and do not be stiff-necked any longer.
verses.comment: 'Circumcise the foreskin of your heart' is a metaphor for inner repentance.

verses.text: For the LORD your God is God of gods and Lord of lords, the great, mighty, and awesome God, who does not show partiality or take bribes.
verses.comment: Divine titles retain Hebrew emphasis.

verses.text: He executes justice for the fatherless and the widow, and loves the foreigner, giving him food and clothing.
verses.comment: The term 'foreigner' refers to resident aliens or sojourners.

verses.text: Therefore, love the foreigner, for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Motivation for loving strangers is based on Israel’s own history.

verses.text: Fear the LORD your God. Serve Him, hold fast to Him, and swear oaths in His name.
verses.comment: Commands for exclusive loyalty; 'hold fast' means to cling, attach oneself.

verses.text: He is your praise; He is your God, who has done for you these great and awesome things that your eyes have seen.
verses.comment: 'He is your praise' means He is the One Israel should praise.

verses.text: Your fathers went down to Egypt seventy persons, but now the LORD your God has made you as numerous as the stars of heaven.
verses.comment: Reference to God's promise to Abraham; number matches Genesis.
